div1.p:
That The scope of government is always to be kept very broad and ample—The question that is to must premise all enactments is must be
Is Will this appealapply to universal men and women universally? Has Does it reference directly or indirectly to
preserve defend the rights to life, liberty and property, of each and all
men and women uncriminal man and woman without any exception whatever?
Whatever is not that broad

* The government to suit these state is no government of lawyers, Dilletanti or — nor a government of Dilletante either.— .— In government politics , in poems, in war, in behavior, one thing tells forever — and that is
fitnessapprop purpose
ability
capability
.— Not gab, not being genteil. not plenty of money,— none of these avail save a new country.
The substratum on which the American constitution is based, is, that every uncriminal person is endowed with the right to be his or her life, liberty, and the equal pursuit of happiness.—

* In what respect does the government of this land represent the strong live American people of this land, this day, or any of these days? —
Is there one. —
It is Where is not Is this crowdmelange of dragon attorneys, feverish
southern dyspeptics —
owners of slaves
seekers of contracts,
bleeders of the treasury,
bullies without courage,
angry dyspeptical speakers from the north,
supple human hinges from the same,
are they this great America? this Pres scum this poor scum that has floated somehow into the presidency those supple

secretaries — these milliners of diplomats (sent forth in their milliner's liveriespoppy show to speak
show dance for us in foreign lands the cotillions of distant courts—
— these are they America? — Are they the great nation? of thirty-two nations

Go back to first principles — nothing through parties. I man a slave who,
him
,
swallows
receives obeys the commands authority of any party, whatever no matter how specious their pretentions. — Listen to all, learn from all, consider well what they have to offer, but obey yourself only. — There They who pull the fabricate the creeds and commands of these parties, are all infidels and scorners of you — they have no faith in man — they do not dream of any other way to success
but except schemings, caucuses, lies lying not not one lie, but all lies — not one face, but a face for every different interestsection
I tell you these men are all using you.
The business performances of government must be reduced to minims

Two Out of any thirty laws enactments, passed by the state legislature Congress of these states, or by the legislatures, twenty nine are for petty personal objects, in which the people have no broad interest whatever.—

p.add: ThinkLearn upon all subjects for yourselves.—(Learn from all sides, but decide for yourselves.

div1.p: The remedy is not in authority, but in the throwing off of authority.— Then Then when false usurper that which abdicates, is replaced by after his work is done and was an usurper allowed to do certain work, comes the true power comes into possession.— I say It is not this or that party who is going to save America, and make it justify the mighty prophecies and promises which are all that it has hitherto been.— It is in countless breeds of great
individuals, the eternal and only anchor of states.—

I have been informed that it is expected ?
that Those who address the people, are expected to will flatter them. I flatter none.— I come to rebuke think that I could taunt you rather than to flatter you.—
What have you been about that you have allowed these that scum to be floated into the Presidency? What have you been about that
Can you find nothing but

Do you think nothing Your Congress is filled with little but gab, college-stuffing book knowledge , and tailors tailors clothes, is ever wanted in your Congress blather doughfaces, and blatherskites puttyfaces?

lg.l:
It never tires of turns so stainless on its axis
with for all those
successions of diseased
corpses,

It
distils distills
such its such winds
and perfumes out
of such such
bequeathed infused
maladies f‘tor.

It renews so faithfully
with such unwitting looks its
prodigal annual sumptuous crops,

It gives such divine
materials to men, and
receives such leavings
in return at last !

div1.head: The Insects
div1.p: get from Mr. Arkhunt a list of just American insects —
? Just simply enumerate them with their sizes, colors, habits, lives,— shortness or length of life,
what they feed upon
(a little poem, of a leaf, or two leaves, only)
div1.transpose: I dare not be too assuming over them.
div1.p: end the insects— First enumerate the insects — Then end by saying

lg.l: I do not know what these are but

I believe that all these
are more than they
I do not knowdeem what they are
I have advised with myself ...

... I dare not consider
myself in any more for my place than
they are for their places

That
know, then
which I do not know,

I need no assurances ... I am
he who is pre-occupied

O I am terrified at the
earth—it is so thatcalm
and patient!

It does gives such things values
?
to man, and receives
these
what they make such leavings bring
themselves at last!

It receives
covers up
those
evil
foul
corruptions, and
grows blossoms and
grass thence
such sweet things
out of such corruptions

is dropped from the cow
and the colt from the
mare.
The The

know do not doubt that

From
under the very steps, and hands,
That
besides what I eyes am
cognizant of, are
calm and looking faces I
am not cognizant of—
calm and silent faces.

I do not doubt but there
is far more in myself
more in my poems, than
more in myself than
I have supposed ... and
more in all men and
women ... and more in
my poems than I
have supposed,

The bol Buds bud from swiftly form upon the
vines

The she birds of morning and
evening, carol build
their nests or brood
on their eggs them—the he-birds
carol on the trees,
mornings and evenings.

The animals young young
of fowls poultry an break
through the hatched
eggs,

The animals new born of animals
appear—the from
cow the cow the calf

I do not doubt there
are more experiences
and growths for me
through time, and
through the universes,
of which I cannot
have the slightlest
inkling or idea

I do not doubt the
universes are limitless
... in vain I try to
fancy how limitless

I do not doubt it is
eternally safe for the
mighty orbs and systems
of orbs to play play than
swift eternal
plays sports through
Behold the fibred lawn regular

Yet The delicate apple blossoms

The resurrection of the

pale visage in its
field out of its graves,

The tinge awakes over willow and the mulberry

the air—and that I shall
one day shall be eligible to
do as much as they, and
more than they,

I do not doubt, that
whatever can possibly
happy through any of the

in the nature inherences of things,

I do not doubt, whatever
can happen in this
world, interior or exterior,
in America, in the other
remainder of the
centuries
earth ,
as in pol among affairs,

amply provided for

I do not am amazed how
the earth sows wherein
is vital and calm

Here in this This is the compost one of
billions of diseased premature corpses,

Perhaps every grain mite has once
formed part of a sick
person.
Yet behold! the shorn earth

Behold how The green grass
upon the praries!

O Mother did you think there
could ever be a time
when I might not

I walk forth amid the calmness
of grass and foliage

But after a little time I
will return among men

I do not see how the
earth nothing but maladies
can be buried resolved back in

otherwise

div1.head: an item for conversation everywhere—
div1.p: To be simple, nature, as native as animals are native—dismissing all the chat, talk of business or money, meaningless talk, criticising acquaintances and their faults—
To be silent unless something must be said that cannot be left unsaid.
Never to attempt to be witty, or choose after effects—not one any how
To dismiss the usual amiable acquiescence also—
